description: From Middle English lard, from Old French lard (“bacon”), from Latin lārdum, lāridum (“bacon fat”).

entries.meaning: Fat from the abdomen of a pig, especially as prepared for use in cooking or pharmacy.
(obsolete) Fatty meat from a pig; bacon, pork.
(slang) Excess fat on a person or animal.
examples: My wonderful partner is fond of pointing out that he and I have done the Covid crisis on easy mode: we have no children, no caring responsibilities,  […]  we have a fabulous community of people at our local fitness studio to keep the lockdown lard at bay and the cats love joining us for afternoon naps.

description: From Middle English larden, from Old French larder and Medieval Latin lārdō.

verbs.description: lard (third-person singular simple present lards, present participle larding, simple past and past participle larded)

entries.meaning: (cooking) To stuff (meat) with bacon or pork before cooking.
To smear with fat or lard.
examples: In his buff doublet larded o'er with fat / Of slaughtered brutes.

entries.meaning: To garnish or strew, especially with reference to words or phrases in speech and writing.

examples: [The oak] with his nuts larded many swine.

entries.meaning: To mix or garnish with something, as by way of improvement; to interlard.
